newsitem.title: UK: Thai exporter sees 96/97 sugar output at 6.3 m tns.
newsitem.headline: Thai exporter sees 96/97 sugar output at 6.3 m tns.

text.p: Thailand should set a new record for sugar production in 1996/97 and turn out 6.30 million tonnes tel quel after 6.03 million the previous year, a leading private Thai exporter said on Wednesday.

Citing Industry Ministry figures, Pichai Kanivichaporn said Thailand's domestic sugar requirement was estimated at 1.70 million tonnes in 1996/97, which would leave an exportable surplus of 4.60 million tonnes.
Kanivichaporn, managing director of the Bangkok-based KSL Trading Company, was delivering a prepared speech at a seminar hosted by the International Sugar Organization (ISO).
Cane production would reach at least 60 million tonnes, compared with 57.69 million last crop year, and Thailand's sugar exports were forecast at 4.38 million tonnes in 1995/96, he said.
"It should be noted that production growth means more dependence on the export markets because domestic consumption could not absorb all extra sugar," Kanivichaporn said.
"At the same time, growth is ascribable to acreage expansion and yield improvement, but a heavier weight appears to be assigned to the acreage variable."
Such a growth had to be hailed with caution, he said, and sustainable growth was feasible only if the industry became cost-competitive internationally.
Kanivichaporn cited an industry outlook for Thailand's sugar situation for 2001/02, saying cane production would reach 70 million tonnes with a sugar yield of 110 kg per tonne of cane.
